bibl.idno: The Philip S. Hench Walter Reed/Yellow Fever Collection [manuscript] / [collected by] Philip S. Hench ; HEALTHSCI MS-1.

div1.head: Newspaper clipping, The Press-Republic, April 11, 1905
div1.p:
At the meeting of the Men's Literary
Club held last evening at the home of
Dr. J. M. Miller, in East High street,
the paper of the evening was read by
Dr. A. H. Vance on the subject “Dr.
Walter Reed and the Mosquito.”

The paper dealt with the investiga-
tions regarding the mosquito made in
Cuba and the demonstrations showing
that yellow fever is caused by this in-
sect. This discovery, the speaker de-
clared, is one of the most important
ever made in medical science.

Dr. Vance dwelt upon the fact that
this discovery will be of untold value
to the government in building the Pan-
ama Canal, as yellow fever, the most
dreaded of tropic diseases, will thereby
be regulated.

Among those to take part in the dis-
cussion were the Rev. Dr. S. A. Ort,
Dr. R. B. House, General J. Warren
Keifer, Professor A. F. Linn, Dr. John
H. Rodgers, Judge Walter L. Weaver
and the Rev. Dr. A. C. McCabe.

The committee appointed at a for-
mer meeting to draft a memorial for
Judge J. K. Mower, for several years
a member of the club, reported last
evening, and the memorial was ordered
spread on the minutes.

A communication was received from
the Men's Club of the First Congrega-
tional Club relative to the formation
of a Civic League for the purpose of
promoting the welfare of municipal af-
fairs, but as the club was organized
for literary purposes only, no action
was taken regarding the communica-
tion.
